Comments_List: I developed a much stronger sense of the forms and strategies contained within the autobiography genre.

The best part of the class is you can apply the strategies you learn to your own writing and see it improved because of that. The weakness is that the grad school students either haven't done the reading or choose not to speak, since participation is not part of the grade, and so that means sometimes a few undergrads carry the class, along with Professor Stepto, who has a propensity to speak for a while.

The syllabus in this class was very well considered. I liked that the books were organized by theme rather than just chronologically, and I liked that Professor Stepto came in with a plan of the major themes of each book. Sometimes I felt like class discussions were not great, since people did not necessarily participate in the discussions unless explicitly asked by the professor.
You might think you can only write one autobiography. But there are many ways if you take this class.

Take this course just so you can get to know Professor Stepto he is incredibly kind and knowledgable, and clearly cares so much about teaching. The books are all interesting and the class is extremely low-stress with a high payoff.
